newsitem.title: ALBANIA: Albania protesters keep pressure on government.
newsitem.headline: Albania protesters keep pressure on government.

text.p: Anti-government protests in Albania showed no sign of abating, with angry investors who lost millions of dollars in savings vowing to keep up pressure until the right-wing government quits.
Sporadic violence, a blockade of the main north-south road and anti-government protests kept tensions high in this Balkan country.
Protests were reported in half a dozen towns in southern Albania, where hundreds of millions of dollars were pumped into the get-rich-quick investment schemes over the past five years.
Even some members of the Democratic Party of Prime Minister Aleksander Meksi have begun calling for the government to admit failure, quit and let a new cabinet be formed.
Gezim Zile, a member of the ruling Democratic Party and the Vlore mayor, called on Friday for the government to resign over its failure to contain a monthlong financial crisis.
"They have done nothing to help the people. They must go," Zile told Reuters in an interview.
He was the first mayor from the ruling party to call for Meksi to quit. Vlore was rocked by protests this week. Three people died and 150 others were injured.
Demonstrators called for an 11th day of protests against the government on Saturday. Similar protests were expected in a half dozen towns in southern Albania.
Scuffles broke out in Fier, also south of Tirana, when 100 riot police tried to keep several thousand protesters from the town's square on Friday.
Protesters, enraged after men attacked a demonstration on Thursday, threw stones at police who quickly gave ground, leaving an uneasy calm.
Protesters erected three barricades on the north-south road between Fier and Vlore, cutting the landlink between Albania's second port and the capital in Tirana.
"We want to separate from the rest of Albania, we do not recognise (President Sali) Berisha any more," one protester shouted at motorists trying to get through.
Several hundred demonstrators in the southern town of Gjirokaster lit candles in the evening and formed the word "Vlore" in a show of solidarity.

Hundreds of protesters carrying bouquets of flowers turned out in Elbasan, south of Tirana. One of the slogans of the main opposition Forum for Democracy is "With flowers, not stones". Protests were reported in the port of Durres and in Cerrik.
Albania, Europe's poorest country, has been swept by protests and riots by investors who lost their life savings in failed investment schemes.
The schemes lured new money with offers of high interest rates and then used the cash to pay earlier investors. A large proportion of Albania's adults seem to have joined the schemes.
Investors blame Berisha's party for letting the schemes flourish and opposition parties accuse him of using cash from the schemes to finance an election campaign last year.

The government, in turn, says opposition groups are trying to exploit the crisis. It impounded about $300 million from two failed funds but steadfastly refused to use government money to reimburse luckless investors.

The head of the state Savings Bank, Bedri Collaku, said $4.3 million had been distributed so far to investors in the failed Populli scheme. The government froze more than $100 million of Populli's assets last month.
Some estimates put the losses from the collapsed schemes at $2 billion, about the size of Albania's annual gross domestic product. Five national schemes have now officially gone bust.
Four more companies, which deny they are pyramids and say they are corporate holdings, have drastically cut back their interest payments and have frozen depositors' assets.
Privately, some officials doubt that cheated investors in Vlore or elsewhere will see any of the money they have lost.
"There is no way anybody would get their money back. It's gone," one local Vlore official told Reuters, requesting anonymity. "But I cannot say that openly -- they will kill me."
